title: The History of the Guitar
subtitle: The history of the instrument who changed the world of music
description: This project stems from  an overview of string instruments, particularly guitars, which have marked an important turning point in the history of music. You will discover how the guitar has influenced not only culture and music, but also the sales market.

dynamic_elements.text: A stringed instrument refers to any musical instrument that produces sound by the vibration of stretched strings. This vibration creates many different types of stringed instruments: 449 is the number of types of stringed instruments existing in the world.
This number includes, however, many other realities, in particular the world of the guitar. Here only the guitar types go up to 42832 different models.
Let’s now take a look at how the sounds of guitar are produced, based on the components of this instrument. Below, you are shown with a table with the different components that make up a guitar.

It can be seen from this table that the material that gives life to these instruments is wood. Almost all components are made of wood; in fact, wood is one of the factors that most influences the sound of a guitar. Its quality allows the strings to vibrate differently and determines the tone of the instrument. Yet is it always just one type of wood? The answer is no. In fact, a specific wood is used for each guitar model. Depending on the model of the guitar (e.g., Gibson ES-333), in fact, we will have different types of wood (e.g., poplar wood, maple wood, mahogany wood and rosewood).

dynamic_elements.textsearch_title: Types of wood employed for guitars

dynamic_elements.text: The presence of various types of guitars gives rise to different market demands, which vary according to the uses and types most valued by the guitar users. Here, then, are shown as indicators two different tables that present by year and sales, the number of electric guitars and acoustic guitars sold over a period of time from 1990 to 2016.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?label (COUNT(?date) AS ?count) 
WHERE { ?guitar ?a wd:Q31561 . 
       ?guitar wdt:P571 ?date .
       SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". ?date rdfs:label ?label. }
              FILTER(YEAR(?date)  >= 1990 && YEAR(?date) <= 2020)
      } 
GROUP BY ?label 
ORDER BY ASC(?label) 

LIMIT 30

SELECT DISTINCT ?label (COUNT(?date) AS ?count) 
WHERE { ?guitar ?a wd:Q78987 . 
       ?guitar wdt:P571 ?date .
       SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". ?date rdfs:label ?label. }
              FILTER(YEAR(?date)  >= 1990 && YEAR(?date) <= 2020)
      } 
GROUP BY ?label 
ORDER BY ASC(?label) 

LIMIT 30

dynamic_elements.text: As we can seen, not only do we have a greater number of sales of electric guitars, but more importantly these are concentrated around 1995, a year when rock-n roll had great success, but also around 2016, a year when the rock revival played an important role in music history. From here, the question arises as to what factors influenced these sales: hence, in the chart below the most influential guitarists who boosted guitar sales are shown.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?label (COUNT(distinct ?band) as ?count) 
WHERE {
     ?band wdt:P1303* wd:Q6607.
     ?band wdt:P737 ?influencer .
          SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en".
          ?influencer rdfs:label         ?label.
      }
}

GROUP BY ?label ?count 
ORDER BY DESC(?count)
LIMIT 20

dynamic_elements.text: The influence of American guitarists has since spread throughout the world and thus, as the map shows us, different countries have a greater or lesser number of guitarists who have influenced the single cultures in their own countries (eg., Fabrizio De Andrè in Italy).

dynamic_elements.map_points_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?pointLabel ?countryLabel ?lat ?long
WHERE {
?point  wdt:P1303 wd:Q6607 .
  ?point wdt:P27 ?country.
?country p:P625 ?statement .  
?statement psv:P625 ?node. ?node wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat ; wikibase:geoLongitude ?long.
SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". } }
LIMIT 500
